turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: They may be looking for us, James.  Use this.  You can fix it in the Men's Room.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I was here...as a kid.  I think you were here, too.  But you...looked just like you look now.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: James, if we're identified, they're going to send us someplace...but not to Key West!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Right!  You're right.  I have to fix this.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: I'll get the tickets and meet you... in the Gift Shop.

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: Does this bother you, Mr. Cole?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: No!  Look, I don't belong here!  What I need to do is make a telephone call to straighten everything out.

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: Who would you call, Mr. Cole, who would straighten everything out?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Scientists.  I'm supposed to report in to them.  They'll want to know they sent me to the wrong time.

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: So you could talk to these scientists and they do what?  Send you to the future?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: No, no.  I can't talk to them.  It's called, "voice mail".  I'm supposed to leave messages. They monitor it from the present.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: What'd they give you?  Thorazine?  How much?  Learn your drugs -- know your doses.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I need to make a telephone call.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: A telephone call?  That's communication with the outside world!  Doctor's discretion.  Hey, if alla these nuts could just make phone calls, it could spread.  Insanity oozing through telephone cables, oozing into the ears of all those poor sane people, infecting them!  Whackos everywhere!  A plague of madness.  In fact, very few of us here are actually mentally ill.  I'm not saying you're not mentally ill, for all I know you're crazy as a loon.  But that's not why you're here.  Why you're here is because of the system, because of the economy.  There's the TV.  It's all right there. Commercials.  We are not productive anymore, they don't need us to make things anymore, it's all automated.  What are we for then?  We're consumers.  Okay, buy a lot of stuff, you're a good citizen. But if you don't buy a lot of stuff, you know what?  You're mentally ill! That's a fact!  If you don't buy things...toilet paper, new cars, computerized blenders, electrically operated sexual devices...  SCREWDRIVERS WITH MINIATURE BUILT-IN RADAR DEVICES, STEREO SYSTEMS WITH BRAIN IMPLANTED HEADPHONES, VOICE- ACTIVATED COMPUTERS, AND...

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Germs?!

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: In the 18th century there was no such thing!  Nobody'd ever imagined such a thing -- no sane person anyway.  Along comes this doctor...Semmelweiss, I think.  He tries to convince people... other doctors mostly...that there are these teeny tiny invisible "bad things" called germs that get into your body and make you...sick!  He's trying to get doctors to wash their hands.  What is this guy...crazy?  Teeny tiny invisible whaddayou call 'em?..."germs"!

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: "What about the germs?"  I say.  He goes, "I don't believe in germs.  Germs are just a plot they made up so they can sell you disinfectants and soap!" Now, he's crazy, right?  Hey, you believe in germs, don't you?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I'm not crazy.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Of course not, I never thought you were. You want to escape, right?  That's very sane.  I can help you.  You want me to, don't you?  Get you out?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: If you know how to escape, why don't you...?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Why don't I escape, that's what you were going to ask me, right?  'Cause I'd be crazy to escape!  I'm all taken care of, see?  I've sent out word.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: What's that mean?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: I've managed to contact certain underlings, evil spirits, secretaries of secretaries, and assorted minions, who will contact my father. When he learns I'm in this kind of place, he'll have them transfer me to one of those classy joints where they treat you...properly. LIKE A GUEST!  LIKE A PERSON!  SHEETS! TOWELS!  LIKE A BIG HOTEL WITH GREAT DRUGS FOR THE NUT CASE LUNATIC MANIAC DEVILS...

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: They hurt you!

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Not as bad as what they're doing to kitty.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Look at those assholes, they're asking for it!  Maybe people deserved to be wiped out!

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Wiping cut the human race!  That's a great idea!  But it's more of a long term thing -- right now we have to focus on more immediate goals.  I didn't say a word about "you know what".

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: What are you talking about???

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: You know -- your plan.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: What're you writing?  You a reporter?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: It's private.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: A lawsuit?  You going to sue them?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Wooooo, they really dosed you, bro. Major load!  Listen up -- try and get it together.  Focus!  Focus!  The plan! Remember?  I did my part.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: What...???

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Not, "what", babe!  When!

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Never saw him before in my life.  Go ahead and shoot him or torture him or whatever it is you do.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You do know me.  You helped me once.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: That would be totally out of character. Helping people is against my principles.  See, he definitely doesn't know me.  Now, I'm going to go back and listen to my father's very eloquent discourse on the perils of science WHILE YOU TORTURE THIS INTRUDER TO DEATH.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I'm here about some monkeys.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Excuse me -- what did you say?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Monkeys.  Twelve of them.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: County Hospital, right?  1989.  The "Immaculate Escape" -- am I right?  Why, thank you -- you look wonderful, too.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Listen to me -- I can't do anything about what you're going to do. I can't change anything.  I can't stop you.  I just want some information...

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: We need to talk.  Come on.  Upstairs.  I am a new person!  I'm completely adjusted.  Witness the tux.  It's Armani.  Who chattered?  Goines?  Weller?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I just need to have access to the pure virus, that's all!  For the future!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I don't have time to go upstairs.  The police are looking for me.  I need to know where it is and exactly what it is.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: I get it!  This is your old plan, right?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Plan?  What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Remember?  We were in the dayroom, watching TV, and you were all upset about the...desecration of the planet. And you said to me, "Wouldn't it be great if there was a germ or a virus that could wipe out mankind and leave the plants and animals just as they are?"  You do remember that, don't you?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Bulishit!  You're fucking with my head!

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: And that's when I told you my father was this famous virologist and you said, "Hey, he could make a germ and we could steal it!"

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Listen, you dumb fuck!  The thing mutates We live underground!  The world belongs to the fucking dogs and cats.  We're like moles or worms.  All we want to do is study the original...

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: JOSE!

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: Cole!  Oh, God, Cole, where are we?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Jo...Jose????

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: Pulling out the tooth, man, that was nuts!  Here, take this.

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: Me?  Are you kiddin?  You're the one! You were a hero, man.  They gave you a pardon!  And whadda you do?  You come back and fuck with your teeth!  Wow!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: How did you find me?

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: The phone call, man.  The phone call.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: The call I just made?  Five minutes ago?

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: Hey, five minutes ago, thirty years ago! Yes, that phone call.  I been in training for this a couple a months now -- ever since I got back from that... "weird" war we were in.  You remember that?  Here, take it, man!  You could still be a hero if you'd cooperate!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: This part isn't about the virus, is it?

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: Hey, man...

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: It's about obeying, about doing what you're told.

turns.speaker: JOSE
turns.text: They gave you a pardon, man.  Whatdaya want?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Who am I supposed to shoot?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I mashed the spider, didn't I?

turns.speaker: MICROBIOLOGIST
turns.text: We'll get to the spider later, Mr. Cole.  Right now, we want to know everything that you saw.

turns.speaker: MICROBIOLOGIST
turns.text: I asked you, why did you volunteer?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Well, the guard woke me up.  He told me I volunteered.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Uh, that message...me?

turns.speaker: MICROBIOLOGIST
turns.text: It's a digital reconstruction of a message, Cole, from a weak signal on our contact number.  Did you make that call?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: I couldn't call!  You sent me to the wrong year!  It was 1989.

turns.speaker: MICROBIOLOGIST
turns.text: But you know what's real now?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: Don't be defensive, Kathryn, this isn't an inquisition.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: I didn't think I was being defensive. I was just...

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: He should have been in restraints.  It was bad judgment on your part, plain and simple.  why not just cop to it?

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: Okay, it was bad judgment.  But I have the strangest feeling about him -- I've seen him somewhere and...

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: Two policemen were already in the hospital and now we have an orderly with a broken arm and a Security Officer with a fractured skull.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: I said it was bad judgment!  What else do you want me to say?

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: You see what I mean?  You're being defensive.  Isn't she being defensive, Bob?

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: He was fully sedated!

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: Then are you trying to tell me that a fully sedated, fully restrained patient somehow slipped out that vent, replaced the grill behind him and that he's wriggling through the ventilation system right now?

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: He kidnapped you, Kathryn.  You saw him murder someone.  You knew there was a real possibility he would kill you, too.  You were under tremendous emotional stress.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: For God sakes, Owen, listen to me -- he knew about the boy in Fresno and he says three billion people are going to die!

turns.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
turns.text: Kathryn, you know he can't possibly know that.  You're a rational person. You're a trained psychiatrist.  You know the difference between what's real and what's not.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: And what we believe is what's accepted as "truth" now, isn't it, Owen?  Psychiatry -- it's the latest religion.  And we're the priests -- we decide what's right and what's wrong --we decide who's crazy and who isn't. ... I'm in trouble, Owen.  I'm losing my faith.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: What...virus?

turns.speaker: DR. MASON
turns.text: She knew about it, Jeffrey.  She knew you were going to try this.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: What virus are we talking about, Dad?

turns.speaker: DR. MASON
turns.text: You're insane, Jeffrey.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: You "develop" viruses and you're calling me insane?  Typical.  What does this virus attack?  Don't tell me, you sick fuck, it doesn't matter.  Have I ever "developed" a virus?  Do I put helpless animals in cages and measure their reactions to electrical stimuli? Do I inject radioactive substances into living creatures and examine their bowel movements?  Wow!  And I'm crazy!

turns.speaker: DR. MASON
turns.text: Please tell me, Jeffrey, what exactly are you going to do?  I don't have to tell you I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: THIS IS A FUCKING EXPERIMENT!  YOU'RE OUR HELPLESS LITTLE TEST ANIMAL, DADDY. GOT THAT?  NOW -- WHAT FUCKING VIRUS HAVE YOU COME UP WITH, YOU DEMENTED FUCKING MANIAC?

turns.speaker: FALE
turns.text: One dozen bolt cutters!  Whadda you gonna do with one dozen bolt cutters?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: You really want to know?

turns.speaker: FALE
turns.text: No!  Absolutely not. Don't tell me anything.

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: WHY DON'T WE FORGET MY GODDAMN PSYCHIATRIST AND DEAL WITH THE TASK AT HAND.  THIS IS IMPORTANT.

turns.speaker: FALE
turns.text: Your psychiatrist?  Did you just say, "your psychiatrist"?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: Ex-psychiatrist!  Now, what about flashlights?  How many flashlights...?

turns.speaker: FALE
turns.text: That woman is...was...your... psychiatrist?  And now she's spray- painting our building?

turns.speaker: JEFFREY
turns.text: WHO CARES WHAT PSYCHIATRISTS WRITE ON WALLS?  You think I told her about the Army of the 12 Monkeys?  Impossible!  Know why, you pathetically ineffectual and pusillanimous "pretend-friend-to- animals"?!  I'll tell you why:  because when I had anything to do with her six years ago, there was no such thing -- I hadn't even thought of it yet!

turns.speaker: FALE
turns.text: Then how come she knows what's going on?

turns.speaker: FRANKI
turns.text: -- so they get there and they ask the guy real nice for some kind of i.d., and he gets agitated, starts screaming about viruses. Totally irrational, totally disoriented, doesn't know where he is, what day it is, alla that stuff.  All they got was his name.  They figure he's stoned out of his mind, it's some kinda psychotic episode, so they're gonna bring him...

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: He's been tested for drugs?

turns.speaker: FRANKI
turns.text: Negative for drugs.  But he took on five cops like he was dusted to the eyeballs.  No drugs.  You believe that?

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: You have him in restraints.

turns.speaker: FRANKI
turns.text: Were you listening?  We got two officers in the hospital.  Yeah, he's in restraints, plus the medic gave him enough stellazine to kill a horse.  Look at him!  Still on his feet.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: That would explain the bruises, I guess.  The struggle.

turns.speaker: FRANKI
turns.text: You want to go in?  Examine him?

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: Yes, please.  You said he gave a name...

turns.speaker: FRANKI
turns.text: James Cole.  That's everything we got.  None of the James Coles on the computer match him. No license, no prints, no warrants.  Nothing. You want me to go in with you?

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: FRANKI
turns.text: I'll be right here...just in case.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: Nine thirty

turns.speaker: WOMAN CABBIE
turns.text: Might be tight.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: Tight?  My watch says 7:30.

turns.speaker: WOMAN CABBIE
turns.text: On your normal mornin', okay, plenty a time, but today, gotta take inta account your Army-of-the-Twelve-Monkeys factor.

turns.speaker: RAILLY
turns.text: What?  What did you say?

turns.speaker: WOMAN CABBIE
turns.text: Twelve Monkeys, honey.  Guess you folks didn't turn on your radio this morning.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Hey!  You there!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You want something, old man?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Don't call me old man.  Ain't you got no respect, boy?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You want something?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Yeah I want something.  I want you to run over to that machine and get me a pop.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You can't do that yourself?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Hell no, I can't do that myself. I'm blind.  Can't you see that?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm sorry, I didn't--

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: What'd you think I was doing out here with these glasses on?  Sunnin' myself?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't know.  I thought you were keeping the sun from your eyes.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: I ain't got no eyes.  You want to see?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Christ no!

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Lost my eyes on Okinawa.  Lost them fighting the war.  Fought the war and lost my eyes just so you could come around here and make fun of me.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I said I was sorry.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Don't be sorry.  Just run over there and get me my pop before I die of thirst.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, sure.  You got change?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Change?  You want my change?  I fought the war and lost my eyes just so I could give you my change?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: All right, old man.  Christ.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Get me a Dr. Peppa!  I don't want no Pepsi.  Pepsi ain't nothing but flavored water.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Don't forget to open it for me.  I can't be opening my own bottle.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Christ!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I think you'd better give your pooch a sip.  He looks sick.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: That's 'cause he's dead.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, Jesus.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: I hope you wasn't pettin' him none, was you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What the hell are you keeping a dead dog around for?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: He's only just dead.  What was I supposed to do with him?  I can't take him away anywhere.  And nobody wants to take him for me.  Do you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: He no!

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: See.  Ain't nothing I can do but keep him here beside me.  That's where he belongs anyways.  Me and Jesse, that's my dog, not anymore, but me and Jesse we been pals since the war when I lost my eyes.  He was just a pup then . . .

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You sure seen a lot for a blind man.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Just 'cause I ain't got eyes doesn't mean I can't see.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That a fact?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: I can see just fine.  For example: You're a young man who thinks he's got someplace to be.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Maybe I do.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Or maybe you just think you do.  You can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, there you are.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I think I've heard that before.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: What do you want for free?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You sure got a lot of philosophy, old man.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: That's 'cause I've done a lot of living.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Maybe one day I'll get to sit on a corner and spout wise.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Think you'll live that long?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Ain't you got a little something for the infirm?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm a little short. I'll catch you next time.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: I won't hold my breath.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: The day wasn't so bad.  We all got through it all right.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Ain't over yet.  Night is part of day; separate, but equal.  Night is when you let your guard down; when you see things in the shadows and hear things in the dark.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You're a hell of a pessimist, old man.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Night is when you want to sleep, but the dry heat keeps you tossin' and turnin'.  It's when you wish the sun was bakin' high in the sky so you could see what it is you're afraid of.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You afraid of the dark?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Afraid of it?  Boy, I live in the dark.  People are afraid of what they can't see.  I can't see nuthin', so it's all the same to me. Kiss from a beautiful woman, a lick from a dog.  The kiss of death. It's all the same.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You don't fear death?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: We was born to die, boy.  From the minute you take your first breath you got a death sentence hanging over your head.  You just don't know where, or when, or how.  Don't make sense worryin' about the particulars.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: We're all just floating along like twigs in a stream, so enjoy the ride.  Is that it?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: More or less.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Not this twig, friend.  I got plans.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: We all got plans.  I planned on seeing all my life.  I know you didn't plan on straying into town.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No and I don't plan on sticking around either.  I don't guess I'll be seeing you again.  Take it easy.

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Same back at you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Any parting words of wisdom?

turns.speaker: BLIND MAN
turns.text: Things ain't always the way they seem. You got to ask yourself; is it worth it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'll take a piece of that bet. I say it doesn't come up five times each side.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Well, a man with some gumption.  How much money you got?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: You want to make a kiddies bet?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'll bet my watch against your pay.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's a Movado.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Never heard of it.  It's got no day or date.  Hell, it ain't even got numbers.  What's the matter?  You couldn't afford a Timex?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Next city you're in take it to a jeweler.  He won't give you less than four-hundred for it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Thirty-bucks?  That's it?

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: That's my morning's pay.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm a rich man off of thirty bucks?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: One-hundred-thirteen degrees.  That was back in July of forty-seven. Now there ain't no way it's gonna be hotter than that.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Hundred and eight already.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hundred and eight ain't a hundred and thirteen.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Will be.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You ain't nothing but an old fool.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: You got two years on me.  What's that make me?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: It's nonsense.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: It is not.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: A coin's got two sides.  When you flip it there's a fifty-fifty chance it'll be heads or tails.  Boyd thinks if you flip a coin ten times half the time it'll come up each side.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: It will.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No it won't.  You just don't know shit about statistics.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: And what are you?  A rocket scientist?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I got more brains than you've got teeth.

turns.speaker: BOYD
turns.text: Put your money where your chicken- lipped mouth is.  I'll bet this mornings pay I'm right.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Can I help you, sir?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I need a ticket.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Where to?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Out of here.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: But, in particular?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I . . . Mexico.  You got a bus that goes to Mexico?  That's where I have to go.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Where in Mexico would you like--

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't care, just get me there.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: We have a bus to Mexico.  Arrives in two hours.  Have to make a couple of connections, but it will get you across the border.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How much.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: One way, or round trip?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: One way.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Thirty even.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Twenty-seven, fifty.  That's all I got.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The ticket is thirty dollars.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I bought a beer.  That was two- fifty.  I bought a beer, otherwise I would have thirty.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir.  It's thirty dollars for the ticket.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah.  Just a little short. Figures.  I just wanted to get out, that's all.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Please, you don't understand.  I have to get out of here.  They're going to come looking for me. They're going to kill me.  If I can't get this ticket then I'm going to have to do things to get out of here.  I don't want to hurt anybody, I just want to leave.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: I'll give you the money!  Okay? I'll give you two-fifty.  Just . . . just, please.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: You want somethin'?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You Harlin?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Nope.  Darrell.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Harlin around?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: He's up at the Look Out.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Will he be back soon?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Doubt it.  He's dead.  The Look Out's a cemetery.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You own this place?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Then why do you call it Harlin's?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: 'Cause Harlin used to own it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: But he's dead.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You want to take a look at my car? I think the radiator hose is--

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Damn.  Gonna be another hot one today.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: That'll make five in a row.  Never seen it so hot.  Sometimes I don't even want to get out of bed.  I'd rather just lay there and try to catch a breeze.  I was in Mexico this one time--

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, pal, I've got places to be. Could you just take a look at my radiator hose.  It's busted.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: It's your radiator hose.  It's busted.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I know it's busted.  What did I just tell you?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Well, you know so much why don't you just fix it yourself?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: If I could do you think I'd be standing here wasting my time.  Can you fix it, or do I have to go somewhere else?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Somewhere else?  Mister somewhere else is fifty miles from here.  How you planning on getting it there? You gonna push this heap yourself?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Okay, I'm stuck.  You happy?  Now can you fix it, or not?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Yeah, I can fix it.  Gotta run over to the yard and see if I can find a hose like this one, or close enough. Gonna take time.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How much time?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Time.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What time is it now?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Twenty-after-ten.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus.  Twenty-after-ten and it must be ninety already.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Ninety-two.  Only gonna get hotter. I remember one time . . .

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Accident.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: You got to be more careful.  I remember one time--

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, right.  Someplace in this dust bowl I can get something to drink?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Truck stop up a piece.  Not much, but us simple folk like it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'll be back in a couple of hours. And be careful with her, will you?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Just a car.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Hey, your . . . what the hell happened to you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Don't look like nothing.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Just banged my head.  It was an accident.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Another accident?  You got to be more careful.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, I just want to pick up my car.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: She's all yours. Put a new hose in it, and she runs like a dream now.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Well . . . parts, labor . . . let's call it a hundred-fifty bucks.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How much!?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Hundred-fifty.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: To replace a God damn radiator hose!?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: A God damn radiator hose in a sixty- four-and-a-half Mustang.  You know how long it took me to find that hose?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: About an hour and a half, because that's all the longer I've been gone.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: That's about an hour and a half longer than I usually spend looking for parts.  You're the one thinks that car's so damn fancy.  What you expect but fancy damn prices?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's a Ford, not a Ferrari.  You going to tell me no one else in this shit hole drives a Ford?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: That's not just a Ford, that's a sixty-four-and-a-half Mustang.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What's that got to do with the radiator hose?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: I don't know, but it's the reason I'm living here and you're just passing through.  Now you owe me a hundred-fifty dollars.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It might as well be fifteen-hundred dollars, because I don't have the money.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Then you ain't gonna have the car.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Listen, man.  I got rolled half and hour ago for everything I had.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Then you're only a hundred-forty- five in the hole.  Now why don't you just take your Visa Express Silver Card, call Karl Malden and have him send you the money lickity split.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't have a credit card.  They took my wallet.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Now that's too bad.  I sure hope you know how to wash dishes or shovel shit 'cause you're gonna have to work this one off.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You son of a bitch!

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Sweet talk me all you want, I still want my hundred-forty-five dollars.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Hey there.  I was beginnin' to think you wasn't comin' back.  You don't look so good.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, well, I've been around the bend a bit.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: One of those days you feel like you been runnin' in circles and you ain't no closer to where you tryin' to get than when you started?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You've been there?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Hell, I've had days I would gladly trade with a whippin' dog.  Ain't much you can do when you feel like that 'cept tough it out.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You believe that?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: You think bad, and bad is what you get.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's a good piece of advice, Darrell.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: No charge.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Listen, Darrell, about that hundred- fifty bucks for the car, as soon as I get where I'm going I swear I'll--

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Two-hundred.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: It's going to cost you two-hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You said this morning the hose was going to run me one-fifty.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Yep.  For the hose.  But while you was gone I replaced a gasket. That's going to run you another fifty.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I didn't tell you to replace any gasket.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Yeah, but it was shot.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I didn't tell you to do it!  You can't just do unauthorized work.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Well, now, you just know all there is about bein' a mechanic, don't you?  I can't do unauthorized work. I suppose I can just let you ride out of here with a bad gasket.  Then you get in an accident and get killed.  Or worse.  Who they gonna blame then?  They gonna blame me, and there goes my reputation.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What reputation?  You're nothing but an ignorant, inbred, tumble weed hick.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Is that an insult?  Are you insulting me.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Listen you stupid fuck, I want my car.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Take it.  As soon as I get my money. Fifty dollars for an almost new gasket.  You don't know what kind of a deal you're getting.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I'm taking my car, and I'm taking it now!

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: You listen to me, you fancy city man.  You owe me money, and this car ain't going nowheres until I get it. And if you take another five hours I'll find another fifty dollars worth of work to do on her.  Now get out of here!  You're stinking up my garage.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: What's the matter?  The fight gone out of you?  I'm just gonna smash a headlight.  Maybe two.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Please, just leave the car alone.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Yeah, you better remember that.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Goddamn you!  You son of a bitch!

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: There you go, sweet talking me again.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: What you want?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Open up!

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: We're closed.  Come back in the morning.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It is morning.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Come back when the sun comes up.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: What the hell . . . oh it's you. Might've figured.  What do you want?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I want my car.

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: You got the money?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: Two-hundred dollars in hundred- dollar bills.  And this morning you was broke.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What's it to you?

turns.speaker: DARRELL
turns.text: I don't want no dirty money.  I run an honest business.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Honest like Al Capone on tax day. Where are my keys?

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: Now that you're so well off, can I get you something, Hon?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You got beer?

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: What would a truck stop be without beer?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Let me have a Beck's.

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: We ain't got no Beck's.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Kirin?

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: No, we ain't got no Kirin.  We got Miller.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Genuine Draft?

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: No.  We got Miller.  Regular Miller. You want it, or don't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, give me the Miller.

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: Shasta!  Now why'd you go and scare the nice man like that?  Sorry about that, hon.  Enjoy your beer, and try to have a nice day.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, I'll try.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: What was that all about?

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: You know how that Toby is.  Thinks every man he sees is after his Jenny.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: More like Jenny is after every man she sees.

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: You pay Toby no mind.  He just likes to show off for his girl.  Give him a couple of hours, he'll cool off. Still want that beer?

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: Poor thing.  Is she all right?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: 'Cept that she lost her money and the sons of bitches stole her wedding ring.  That's when she started shooting.  Can't blame her. The ring was all Carlos left her when he died.

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: Lord!  Put the baby in the icebox. Killed the poor thing.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Baby didn't die.  Just froze off all it's finger and toes.  Just a little fingerless, toeless boy now.  But the husband; he sees what the wife's done, so after he saves the baby he locks the wife in the refrigerator to see how she likes it.  Now she died.

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: Let me get your change.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Flo, I'm just gonna help myself to a refill on the coffee.

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: Ned!  Now look at what you done! Are you all right?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: I think I burned my gun hand!

turns.speaker: FLO
turns.text: It'd serve you right.  Jose, run get a mop and clean this mess up.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: That yours, Mrs. McKenna?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Yes.  Yes it is.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Taking a little trip?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I had a fight with Jake.  I . . . I just wanted to get away for awhile. Mr. Stewart was kind enough to take me as far as Montrose.  I'm going to take a bus to my sister's.  I thought I'd stay with her for a few days.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Is that right?  Can't say as I blame you for wanting to head out for a bit.  I know I've had my fill of this town.  Sixteen years I've been the law and order here.  So long I forgot why I ever wanted the job in the first place.  Help people, I guess.  Keep the peace.  Problem is there's so much peace around here they don't much need me.  Got a lot of speeders, but they're speeding through miles of nothing so I can't hardly blame them.  Other than that, well, there ain't much to steal.  I reckon that the last big crime we had was, what would you say Mrs. McKenna?  A murder?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: I could do that.  'Course we'd have to go back into town.  There'd be a whole crowd of people around when the trunk was opened.  A whole crowd of witnesses.  That wouldn't be too pretty, now would it?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: John . . .

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Is that the way you want it, boy?  A bullet in the head in the middle of the desert?  Ends like this and you won't be able to spend a dime of that blood money.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: He killed him, Sheriff!  I couldn't stop him!  He made me come with him. He told me if I said a word he would kill me too.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: For the love of God would you two give it a rest?  Lord almighty.  In all my years I have never seen anything so pathetic.  How far did you think you were going to get with this?  Neither one of you can wait to slit the others throat.  Now use what little smarts you got.  If I was going to bust you I wouldn't have waited until after you killed Jake.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Same thing you want.  I want to be out of Sierra; to be able to do as I please.  But that takes money.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: . . .at the very least.  I know there was more than thirty-thousand dollars.  Now, how much did you get?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Don't tell him anything.  He can't do this.

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: Can't I?  You're out in the desert, all alone, with a body in your trunk.  What do you think, boy?

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: There you go, Mrs. McKenna.  Just put it in there.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: John--

turns.speaker: SHERIFF
turns.text: That wasn't so bad.  What's thirty- some-thousand to rich folks like you?  It didn't hurt a bit.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Sheriff Potter.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Jake.  I thought you would be at work, dear.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Who the hell is this!?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Who was that on the phone?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Wrong number.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You spent a long time talking for a wrong number.  But then you make friends so easily.  Don't you, Grace?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I put up new drapes, Jake.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I know.  I was here when your apprentice was helping you. Remember?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You never said anything.  About the drapes.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: They look nice.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You haven't even looked at them once.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: They look nice.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I picked them out for you, Jake.  I thought you would like the colors.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Uh-huh

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What the hell you looking at, girl?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Nothing, Jake.  Absolutely nothing.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You didn't hear something?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: How could I?  I was sleeping.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: There's someone in the house.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't hear anything.  You were dreaming.  Or maybe the wind blew something over.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: The wind isn't blowing.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Jake, what is that?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What does it look like?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: When did you buy a gun?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Oh my God, Jake, no.  If it is someone they'll go away.  Or call the police.  Don't go out there.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What are you afraid of?  I'm the one's got the gun.  Stay here.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Jake.  No.  No!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Can I give you a hand, beautiful?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I'm just going to my car.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's right on my way.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: My mother told me never to accept offers from strangers.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: My name is John.  Now I'm not a stranger anymore.  See how easy it is for us to get to know each other, beautiful?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Do you have to call me that?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't know your real name.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Maybe I don't want you to.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Maybe, but if you didn't I think you would have kept on walking.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You're pretty full of yourself, aren't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: My cup runneth over, beauti--

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: It's Grace.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: May I carry your package, Grace?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You sure you can manage?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I got it.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Do you want me to carry your pack for you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, I've got it.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What happened to your hand?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Accident.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You should be more careful.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: It's very nice of you to help me. That package is kind of heavy, and it's so hot.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No trouble at all, really.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Wasn't nothing.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Oh, this isn't my car.  It's down a ways.  I should have parked closer. I just didn't think it would be so heavy.  I could drive up.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's all right.  I got it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's nothing.  Really.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I just got tired of looking at the old drapes.  Had them long as I can remember.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That a fact?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I saw these in the Penny's catalog, and I just knew I had to have them. You ever seen something and just knew you had to have it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yes, I have.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: 'Course they cost a little more than I should really be spending.  But, damn it, I don't hardly ever do anything nice for myself.  I deserve nice things.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I . . . can't . . . argue . . .

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Thank you, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You're welcome, Grace.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You're not from around here, are you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Why you say that?  Just because I help a lady with her package?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You don't have that dead look in your eyes like the only thing you live for is to get through the day.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I just drove in this morning.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Drove into Sierra?  What for?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Didn't have a choice.  My car overheated up the road.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Good luck it didn't happen a few miles back.  Maybe they never would have found you.  Day like today you'd be dead for sure.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, my luck.  I get to be stuck out here in this hole in the desert.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Least you can leave.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Not until my car's fixed.  I don't know how long that's going to take.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: And here I've made you all hot and sweaty.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Where you coming from?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: All over.  Chicago, Miami, Detroit. Just lately Albuquerque.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You've been around.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I guess I've got wander in my blood.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Where you headed?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I don't know.  I have to make a stop in Vegas.  Business to finish.  Then maybe I'll head to Santa Barbara.  I might be able to pick up some work there.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You just travel around, no direction, no steady work.  You must like taking chances.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: If you're going to gamble, might as well play for high stakes.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What happens if you lose?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I pack up and go somewhere else.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Somewhere else.  I've never been anywhere else.  Just once.  Years ago.  Went to the state fair.  It was nice, but it wasn't nothing.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I couldn't stay in this place.  I wouldn't.  I'd just pick up, do whatever I had to do, and get out.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's good.  Cools you right off.  I saw you watching me.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I didn't mean to.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I didn't say it bothered me.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Did you like it; me watching you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I guess.  I've got an ego same as any man.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Good, 'cause I liked what I saw.
